entry.title: Secrets of the Site Container: Part 2

link.title: Secrets of the Site Container: Part 2

entry.content:
Containers are functional. Containers are necessary. Without them you‚Äôre exploring the great unknown of horizontal scrolling on a vertical page. Holding shift when you torque the mousewheel. It isn‚Äôt too much to ask to make it beautiful, though, is it?

Well, to be honest, most of the time that answer is yes. Function always comes before form, and things aren‚Äôt going to work better if you add bells and whistles. I really, truly believe that isn‚Äôt just my Pennsylvania Dutch heritage telling me that it doesn‚Äôt get better than hand-built Amish furniture. These hills are in my blood.

But we do need creativity and freedom. We need to show that we aren‚Äôt constrained. Sometimes breaking the rules just enough is proving that you knew the real rules all along. ü•Éüï∂üö¨

What a meta, over-philosophical introduction to another blog about site containers!

Making boxes that aren‚Äôt quite in the middle

What if you want to blow out an image all the way to the side of the screen? No site container on that side. Full width. But the other side matches your margin perfectly. Something like‚Ä¶

Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.

It makes things easier if you consider the two ‚Äòhalves‚Äô of your screen like this:

Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.

The right side of that image is blowing out to 50%! Dead simple. The left side is exactly half of the site container‚Äôs width. The only remaining magic is to push the block toward the side you‚Äôre locking it on with an automatic margin. Here‚Äôs the code for that.

How about a container for text, next to that image? You might be tempted to do heavy math on that. Don‚Äôt do heavy math on that.

Some text on the left
Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.

The code:

Making things that aren‚Äôt a box

Let‚Äôs say you have a thing that isn‚Äôt a square, or doesn‚Äôt require constraining at all. That thing might not flow at the same speed as your page content. It might not even be positioned relative to it. The easy answer for that is position itself. Which has the potential to negate a lot of the power of a site container as well.

position: static;
The default. Should work the same as unset, so this is what you do if you have to override somebody else‚Äôs work, but you also want them to think you‚Äôre smart (read: force them to look up your solution).
position: relative;
Makes everything tick. It‚Äôs a way to set the parent for all of your position children.
position: absolute;
Ignores block positioning. It lets things go on top of (or underneath) other things. It refers back to most recent position-assigned parent to determine its place. If none is available, it‚Äôs positioned on <body> itself. It then uses top, bottom, left, or right to determine coordinates on that element.
position: fixed;
Like absolute on crack. Ignores block positiong and parents. Almost always a terrible idea, especially for accessibility. So of course I‚Äôve used it in a final build!
position: sticky;
The fun uncle. Make things stick at a certain point, but only inside of the parent. Not supported by IE, but generally it doesn‚Äôt matter ‚Äì most standard uses degrade gracefully.

The centered thing.

This might be amateur hour but here‚Äôs how to center a thing that is absolutely positioned.

But did you know, for example, that padding, borders, margins all flow outside of that position?

Here's an example of that. The text will flow normally inside of the container, but you'll have to fix the space around the item separately...
... like this! Account for the padding, the border-width, and the margins. Usually they're the same on both sides of the item, so you can just multiply them by two:
width: calc(100% - (padding + border + margin) * 2);

Position Containers

Containers need to be relatively positioned (if they are positioned at all) to your document‚Äôs <body>, or they will likely lose their pinpoint mathematical accuracy and throw in extra space.

Positioning other things inside of a well-built site container is fair game, as long as you know exactly how big the things are. Using default-styled things like <p> and <h1>? You‚Äôre studdenly worrying about the default bottom margins, and the total height of the element. If something looks off optically, you can use my debugging reticle:

And then there was‚Ä¶ nothing!

You are now a master. I can teach you nothing more. But if you wish, we may start considering the almighty display: grid; and its infinitely complex version of the exact same things I mention above.

Grid is always fun. It is really powerful. But it also reminds me of the days when we encapsulated entire pages in tables. Let‚Äôs save that for layout decisions, menus, and other places where it‚Äôs actually needed!
entry.summary: Containers are functional. Containers are necessary. Without them you‚Äôre exploring the great unknown of horizontal scrolling on a vertical page. Holding shift when you torque the mousewheel. It isn‚Äôt too much to ask to make it beautiful, though, is it?

entry.title: Secrets of the Site Container: Part 1

link.title: Secrets of the Site Container: Part 1

entry.content:
Big screens are getting bigger. Wider. Less expensive. Our web experience should be seamless, but our eyes can‚Äôt adjust to giant blobby things. Containers to the rescue. But first, a digression about font-size and readability!

Disclaimer! This page may scroll horizontally. It's ironic, because it's about site containers.

There‚Äôs a problem with your eyes

You can‚Äôt read long lines of text. The common recommendation is between 45 and 75 characters per line. You may have experienced this issue when you tried to use your TV as a monitor. Wait you never did that? Oh, no, me either üòÖ

Imagine that length as two or three alphabets, back to back. Of course the length of the alphabet depends on how large the character widths are. In this particular body font, I can get a better sense by incorporating capitalized letters. Or I could even use them outright.

Just about this long: abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

Maybe this long: AaBbCcDdEeFfGgHhIiJjKkLlMmNnOoPpQqRrSsTtUuVvWwXxYyZz

Or even this long: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

But really big views are bad too

The unspoken flip-side comes from larger font sizes at a close distance. Making the text larger for larger screens only works until your saccade becomes noticeably uncomfortable. Thus a rather fine case against a purely liquid layout. For large web views, I err on the side of caution. I keep font-size the same on even the largest screens. So something beyond 750px is bad.

Compare the next two paragraphs:

Paragraph 1:

Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit. Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.

abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

Paragraph 2:

Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit. Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.

abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

The larger text made it hard to move from the end of one line to the start of the next. Either it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre scrolling around, or just because your screen was so big that your eye movement was unnatural.

Honestly this doesn‚Äôt really change with non-text items

A huge image doesn‚Äôt help. Even disregarding image sizing and web optimization (our rule at work is twice the pixels for each web pixel, so we get some pretty large picture file sizes!) you‚Äôll quickly lose a picture of a forest for some giant trees.

The solution to this is the same as most other web design problems: a few extra tag wrappers and some CSS. But how is the more important question. That‚Äôs how this blog was born.

Zero. Use appropriate HTML

The sectional approach to site configuration is underrated. A good page has content sections, and they are usually at least 2/3 the height of your browser window. Taking up space and using the infinite scroll canvas that is available to you dramatically increases user interaction and readability. There is also a great reason that HTML has a <section> tag! It‚Äôs for holding this container! Use it like this:

Note: Your section tag might have a full-width background image or other width-breaking things. Don‚Äôt limit yourself by making the section tag itself a container.

One. Start at the maximum, which is actually the smallest.

What‚Äôs the maximum width that your section can be? The answer might not make immediate sense. max-width should be used on your smallest screen sizes. The narrowest screen I‚Äôve seen on devtools is the iPhone 5/SE, weighing in at a mere 325px. If your maximum width is above that, your site will horizontally scroll on that screen. If you use absolute units, your page will forever be confined to 325px.

Don't make your site live in a world that is only 325 px wide, it is a special place where UX dreams go to die and nothing can be accomplished. Two sentences of this took up six lines and looked terrible.

Instead, you need a relative-unit based max-width to account for things. I use percentages, because they are based on your container‚Äôs size. If your container is <body>, that‚Äôs great, but even if you‚Äôre dealing with a strange outer container this won‚Äôt break width as a vw might.

So what percentage? If it‚Äôs a hero section it‚Äôll probably be at the widest your screen allows, but it should never break the horizontal dimensions of your device. So that‚Äôs 100%. Text also needs to breathe, so text on a small screen should be 90-95%. A card or something that is supposed to visually break the monotony of the left edge can creep in more, but after 85% things start to get silly.

Two: Move on to bigger and better screens.

We‚Äôve determined that text should live somewhere between 600px-750px. Once we find that sweet spot, that‚Äôs really the size we want. So let‚Äôs use that as our width!

Other widths will make sense too. Most images look great at between 1280-1500px, your modern laptop screen width. If it‚Äôs a group of cards or items, they might follow the same path, though individual items with paragraphs will follow the same text readability rule.

Our outlying ‚Äòmonotony breakers‚Äô can live somewhere between a paragraph and a hero.

Left of center

Browsers automatically place blocks starting from the left. Your screen probably looks like this:

Well that isn‚Äôt surprising! Block-level elements fill from the left. All you need to do is center those elements on the screen and you‚Äôre set. display: flex; will accomplish this, but changing your overall display feels like overkill. All you need is some sort of automatic margin on both sides of your section, to keep it centered. You know, like margin: 0 auto;.

Tada!

Next steps:

What if you want to blow out the screen, anchoring items to the left or right on one side while maintaining your site container width on the other? It‚Äôs not impossible. I‚Äôll show you how in my next article!

You can also see this blog in action on CodePen.
entry.summary: Big screens are getting bigger. Wider. Less expensive. Our web experience should be seamless, but our eyes can‚Äôt adjust to giant blobby things. Containers to the rescue. But first, a digression about font-size and readability!

entry.title: Less Than 365 Days of Code
entry.content:
You should be a part of your local software community. You need to learn things. You probably don‚Äôt need to learn all of the things, but it‚Äôs good for you to learn most of them. You‚Äôre supposed to be an expert. But you should also probably have a life.

I recently joined Twitter. I jumped on that smoldering, outdated bandwagon. It was a sad day for my productivity. I‚Äôm learning lots of small things, like how to short-circuit instead of using an if block and which order to assign styles for <a> tags. I‚Äôm also learning that it‚Äôs been #100daysofcode since forever, and ‚Äúif you just do this an hour a day, you‚Äôll be famous/rich/happy‚Äù. I don‚Äôt think I want to do Twitter an hour every day.

It‚Äôs July 4th today. Yes, I didn‚Äôt write this ahead of time, it‚Äôs literally the night of July 4th. I‚Äôm sitting here listening to the entire western half of Pennsylvania erupt in joyous war sounds. I am not quite hiding in a closet. Not quite.

Today I played in an inflatable pool. I rode a bike. I ate hot dogs and watermelon and ice cream. I went to a park. But I will tell you what I didn‚Äôt do:

I DID NOT CODE TODAY.

I haven‚Äôt done it since Thursday. I took a few days off. And you should too! This is an underrated and important thing about your life: it is more than your job.

Why you are here

I‚Äôve been trained in classical theology and exegesis. I have some pretty set ideas on why we exist. I‚Äôm going to simplify them a bit for the sake of the unanimous acceptance of my ideas, and also because it would likely bore you.

We exist to do good.

So there‚Äôs the basic doing good with little things, which doesn‚Äôt feel very fun. You can do good by writing your name, and it will please your parents, and maybe you‚Äôll get a few points on the SAT (I am old, I don‚Äôt know this for sure anymore.) If you write it enough, maybe it will look beautiful! Now you‚Äôre sort of pleasing people with art.

That‚Äôs also how your job looks, compared to your life. You can do it well, and get paid money for it, and maybe even sort of please other people with how awesome you are. It‚Äôs important enough, in its own right. Maybe you‚Äôre so good at it that you help other people work. But your job is also a job. If you quit tomorrow, it will no longer be about you. It will no longer be your good.

Ways you can do good

There is a more tangible and lasting good you can do, and it feels better than anything you accomplish for money. For some people, this is having a family. I have a family. They‚Äôre cool. You might have already hear that if you spend one hour every day on your family, you‚Äôre going to have an awesome family. Maybe you can/should spend a little bit more than that. Hey, if I post that on Twitter will 3,000 little birds heart it?

Of course you don‚Äôt need a literal family to do good. Your contributions to your friends and your community make them a little bit like a family too. If you invest in the lives of those people, they might indeed feel that your part of their life was a formative part, and you‚Äôll live on vicariously through their successes, and help to share some of the weight of their tribulations. That‚Äôs also doing good.

How to think about doing good

Maybe the most important part of doing good is that it really isn‚Äôt about you at all. If you‚Äôre doing it right, you are not doing good to achieve something personal. You‚Äôre just pushing up the human race a little bit more.

Whoever wants to save their life will lose it‚Ä¶

It might seem a bit antithetical, but to truly be a good-doer you can‚Äôt be in it for the reward of being a good-doer. You need to be there for the others.

Managers might understand this on another level. To manage people effectively you need to weigh their immediate value to the company, but you also need to consider their needs and ambitions. Honestly investing in your employee‚Äôs wellbeing can very well turn them into an extension of your own will.

This is why it‚Äôs so hard to really do good at a job. I had one of the best good-doer jobs ever. I got to teach kids (in English) how to be world leaders. But I quickly found some major impediments to calling that ‚Äòmy good‚Äô:

I got paid
That was a thing I did for money, and sometimes that fourth-wall was broken, by my students, my coworkers, and even myself.
Other people co-owned that good
Someone was investing money in it, but it wasn‚Äôt me. It was never really my piece of good to begin with. I honestly can‚Äôt see where I ended and it began, anyway.
There was an ulterior motive
You may not understand this if you‚Äôre not in the do-gooder profession. There‚Äôs a specific reason for any public works job. Sometimes you are forced to skip that thing that could really change one life in order to keep doing the good your job needs.

That‚Äôs not to say that I didn‚Äôt try hard to dedicate my time to make up for those situations. I did! But sometimes they were just out of my control.

It‚Äôs been the opposite with my family and social contributions. I felt a stronger impact serving, volunteering, and leading community work than the entire summation of my career. And I feel a certain sort of expectation while watching my son have his own adventures. I have poured my love into him so that he can have a great life, and in return I feel so vicariously happy when he succeeds.

Why did I write this?

Because I think your code isn‚Äôt the only part of you. It shouldn‚Äôt even be the main part. You are alive for a reason, and you are the good you want to see in the world.

So take a break. Refocus on what‚Äôs important. Make love, not war. And please, for the love of humanity, cool it with the fireworks.
entry.summary: You should be a part of your local software community. You need to learn things. You probably don‚Äôt need to learn all of the things, but it‚Äôs good for you to learn most of them. You‚Äôre supposed to be an expert. But you should also probably have a life.

entry.title: WP Custom Post Types but Free

link.title: WP Custom Post Types but Free

entry.content:
Sometimes you‚Äôre good at more than one type of thing. That‚Äôs OK, you‚Äôre human. We like to categorize things and study them logically to distinguish them from each other. We argue about definitions. We like tables. We like lists. We make Custom Types for everything.

What‚Äôs not so OK is if you‚Äôre developing on a ‚Äúsimple‚Äù blog templating tool and you think you can‚Äôt. Those things only do blogs, right? The type of data you‚Äôre storing is a blog. The metadata on those posts is standard. You can‚Äôt well use that for recipes AND blogs. Just make a recipes tag and call it a day.

Luckily that‚Äôs not true at all‚Ä¶ you can automate almost anything you want with a little ingenuity, and automation is the key to efficient web work. In most cases I‚Äôm learning Jekyll was actually built for this sort of automation, but the documentation isn‚Äôt always very helpful to show you how to use it.

Meta-meta

In part one we talked about Liquid, and how to use it to make ACF-like custom fields on your static marketing site. That‚Äôs all well and good if you‚Äôve got individual pages that you want to clone. But what about whole categories of content?

Meta-meta-meta

WordPress calls that stuff Custom Post Types. It‚Äôs based on the idea that you want posts for writing things, but you also want a projects section that shows off your wow mad skillz. You‚Äôd probably like to query those projects independently of the posts. And maybe you‚Äôd like some events, programs, cats, and hairpieces. Your business is not the strangest thing on the internet, I promise.

All of those types are still going to generate data in the same way a blog would. You‚Äôll have an index, an author, a post-date, a title, and some contents. You‚Äôll have a single template for the files, with whatever custom metadata you like, and you can query a list of all of the fields in some format to make it easy for people to search and peruse.

Custom Post Types are called Collections

As we know, Jekyll is a blog generator! Jekyll does the bloggy parts of this just fine. It also has built-in functionality for Custom Post Types that work in tandem with the blog. The creators of Jekyll, having no ties to WordPress that I know of, decided not to name their custom post types Custom Post Types. They call them Collections.

In 5 years of building Jekyll sites, I never came across a Collection. I didn‚Äôt know what it was. (Before I had a full-time development job, I didn‚Äôt even know why I would need something like it.) But it is pretty darn swanky! It can do everything that a WordPress CPT can do, and pre-render the pages as they are built.

Pre-rendered for your viewing pleasure

I will say that again, louder. It can do all of the work to render a list of these blogs one time and store the results to be served instantly. If the build time takes an extra ten minutes, it‚Äôs not a bother for your end users. If you come from a WordPress background (or most full-stack projects), this might take some getting used to.

Old Way of thinking:

This is a common thought process for a WordPress developer:

  • I need only the posts within a certain Post Type, with a certain field.
  • I need to loop through them and grab a connecting ID for other post types.
  • Then I need to loop through those IDs and display their special metadata.

Really bad but easy to follow example

Looping through multiple large queries is going to slow down your page. Maybe you should just index those files yourself in some post meta and make things easier to find. Make a cron and keep things synchronized. If you‚Äôre getting fancy here, you might jump into the database itself with a JOIN. It‚Äôs going to depend a lot on the size of your indexing lines, to be sure.

Real world indexing example

I digress

Once again, you really don‚Äôt have to worry about all that optimization with a static site! It indexes and builds itself. Users will see all that automation like you did it by hand. These days static sites are even smart enough to know when you‚Äôre changing files, and do incremental builds which are smart enough to keep those complicated queries from slowing down your whole site build every time. You won‚Äôt waste time either.
entry.summary: Sometimes you‚Äôre good at more than one type of thing. That‚Äôs OK, you‚Äôre human. We like to categorize things and study them logically to distinguish them from each other. We argue about definitions. We like tables. We like lists. We make Custom Types for everything.

entry.title: Wordpress is a Framework
entry.content:
Lest it fall under the immense weight of my quick and witty Jamstack diatribes, it‚Äôs time I defend my dear friend WordPress from a most misleading misconception. WordPress is not simply a CMS. It might be known for its prowess as a CMS, and modern tools might compare themselves to it, but it is much, much more.

But what is a CMS?

Content Management Systems are systems to organize and deliver (manage) the content of your website in a way that makes sense to you as a business AND integrates with your web framework. That‚Äôs the base definition of a CMS: something that holds the data you need to make your website unique.

WordPress is called a CMS because it has a pretty powerful CMS built into it. It can process files, organize them, and do many things to them based on their type. Image files are stored in multiple different, optimized sizes for use in instances at their most convenient size. The directory which stores all of these things (let‚Äôs call them assets) is pretty confusing to look at, but it is modifiable and it does its job well enough.

And what is a framework?

A web framework on the other hand is a well-known and documented system for deploying content, serving it, and dynamically modifying it. A short and completely unordered list of framework words you‚Äôve probably heard before:

Angular, Django, Rails, CodeIgniter, React, Gatsby, Jekyll, Laravel, nodeJS, RedwoodJS, 11ty

There are front-end frameworks and full-stack frameworks and little tiny frameworks and big, custom frameworks, but they all basically make your website happen. A framework doesn‚Äôt need an integrated CMS, but some frameworks have a bit of an opinion on how to store their media. It‚Äôs not uncommon.

WordPress stores your assets for you

I said the /media directory in WordPress is confusing to look at, because it is. But the the administrator console (WP-admin) is not. It has all.of.the.options. It has all.of.the.settings. It quickly becomes familiar, and it really hasn‚Äôt changed a lot in modern times.

Content Management Systems don‚Äôt need a graphical interface, and they don‚Äôt technically need to store your files. A CMS could be as simple as a JSON file. Some people use JSON files! Isn‚Äôt that techie of them. Can you use this? I probably could, but I‚Äôm lazy. So I don‚Äôt.

WordPress generates your pages

By 2005, static web content in one file was slowly getting replaced by WYSIWYG editing. WYSIWYG editors are a sort of CMS, but they also translate your designs and content into HTML, or style it and place it on the page in special ways.

WordPress also became quite universally recognized for this! The base ‚Äòcontent‚Äô field of every WordPress page or post is a WYSIWYG content editor.

This is a terrible way to build pages in 2020‚Ä¶ but it was very cool at the time.

But these days WP developers use templates to make custom page styles. That‚Äôs a pretty baked-in and dynamic way to organize data. It‚Äôs much more complex than just preserving your content, it‚Äôs actually modifying your output.

WordPress is decently opinionated

One of the great things about software development is ANYTHING IS POSSIBLE. Except that it‚Äôs not that great when you have to reopen a cobwebby legacy project that was developed 10 years ago.

There are many ways to do something, but a Framework tells you one recognized way to do it. WordPress is no different. The WordPress documentation and PHP manual (which I reference quite often) have many specific and accepted ways to do something.

You could build URL parameters by concatenating strings. You could manipulate AJAX requests with JavaScript alone. But WordPress has idiomatic ways to do these things. When they‚Äôre used properly, those idioms become a part of your life. It never made sense to me that $args was an appropriately specific name for an array of details to send through a query request. I didn‚Äôt think writing out array() was necessary. Now I do it every time.

This indicates that WordPress is moderately opinionated about how you should use its tooling. That‚Äôs not a CMS thing, that‚Äôs a Framework thing.

WordPress knows who you are

There are a number of other things that make WordPress much more than a CMS. For instance, a CMS doesn‚Äôt usually take pride in its authentication and user roles, and yet those are a thing that WordPress does. Dwayne Charrington does a decent job of explaining a these in this Quora answer.

Just because it‚Äôs marketed to business as a standardized and easy-to-use product, it‚Äôs entirely unfair to put WordPress in the CMS box.
entry.summary: Lest it fall under the immense weight of my quick and witty Jamstack diatribes, it‚Äôs time I defend my dear friend WordPress from a most misleading misconception. WordPress is not simply a CMS. It might be known for its prowess as a CMS, and modern tools might compare themselves to it, but it is much, much more.

entry.title: WordPress Custom Fields but Free
entry.content:
Cutting-edge web technologies don‚Äôt always document features. Either they lack the ability to convey the full scope of their power from the first release, or they release new features gradually after the MVP. That‚Äôs pretty much the opposite of the old guard of incredible WordPress plugins. A personal favorite static framework of mine is Jekyll, because it‚Äôs simple. But I guess it isn‚Äôt so simple after all.

Jekyll is known as a tool for making your blog. The <h1> on jekyllrb.com is‚Ä¶ uh, well, actually, it‚Äôs the Jekyll logo. But the hero text is ‚ÄúTransform your plain text into static websites and blogs.‚Äù Did you know you can make a blog with Jekyll? If not, perhaps you should reat about it:

‚ÄúJekyll is built with Ruby, and is most often used for blogs and personal projects‚Äù ‚ÄìNetlify

‚ÄúA simple, blog-aware, static site generator‚Äù ‚Äìstaticgen.com

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still great for what it‚Äôs great at‚Äîsmaller websites, blogs and is widely used by e-commerce sites.‚Äù ‚ÄìSnipcart

‚ÄúThis blog was made with Jekyll‚Äù ‚ÄìBenji

Learning all the things you can do with Jekyll is another subject entirely. Here‚Äôs a single page of Jekyll‚Äôs official documentation. It is definitely not the Jekyll team‚Äôs finest moment. I can‚Äôt throw shade, the contributors are doing most of this for free after all! But how could I know that it does pretty much the same things I do at work on WordPress? I couldn‚Äôt. I didn‚Äôt.

Meta-meta

Metadata feels like a good place to start breaking the ‚Äòblog‚Äô idea. In WordPress the most popular metadata tool is called Advanced Custom Fields. ACF allows you to attach images, text, dates, even repeating and iterable internal groups, all within a single page template or custom post type. For each page that uses the template, you can fill in new metadata and create an entirely custom page ‚Äì but with the same format and style. Hence the word template.

Custom metadata is not terribly helpful on a blog. Blogs are mostly unique and custom content. The data that surrounds that content is usually filled in with scaffolding, which follows a lot of specific rules and is very well thought through. So sure, Jekyll has that stuff and it‚Äôs easy to understand, but you don‚Äôt need to make it. It‚Äôs already there.

If you‚Äôre coming from a WordPress background, you already know this. You also know you do need custom metadata when you‚Äôre making pages for things.

And you can do that! Jekyll and many static site generators use Liquid to provide metadata in markdown and HTML page layouts (= templates) and page contents. For the purposes of this blog, it‚Äôs most often the variables with unique names that are stored on top of each page.

I used Liquid to fill in this blockquote.

ACFs on WordPress are cool because you don‚Äôt really have to build everything in WYSIWYG (or write only blogs all day) to make a beautiful page. Liquid on Jekyll is cool because you don‚Äôt really have to read through any HTML to build a page. Let‚Äôs look at an example base layout template:

Example: base_template.html

Liquid is being used in two ways here. It‚Äôs including other templates on the page with {% include %} and it‚Äôs providing dynamic page metadata variables inside of mustachey brackets {{ }}. Those brackets aren‚Äôt confined to page variables. One of the most common variables I use on this site is {{ site.baseurl }} from config.yml. But for the purposes of page-content, yes, you can have these things on each page!

Setting your variables on the page

Now you‚Äôve got the layout, you can require it in the front matter of each page you want to set for that template. Front matter is written in yaml, so if you‚Äôve ever written a docker file you‚Äôre already halfway there. Or‚Ä¶ the other way around!

Example: pagename.md

Output:

Today I am talking about apples. I really don‚Äôt care about them, because they make me fall asleep every time I hear about them. They only cost $5 So at the store: apples cost $5, bananas cost $3, asian pears cost $15

Those arrows above are all of your dynamic data. This markdown below will eventually be where the {{ content }} variable is placed. But this section could also be blank.

Templates gonna template

You can stamp out as many of these templates as you want. In the example above we made 3 pages (with apples, bananas, asian pears), evidenced by the iteration on the final section.

I cannot emphasize enough how exactly the same as WordPress post meta this is, because it is post meta. A free CMS easily adds a graphical interface to the process for people who don‚Äôt want to deal in yaml, but the yaml itself is easy to read. It‚Äôs not a reason for WordPress.

Conclusions

‚ÄúUnique Custom Content‚Äù is such a big deal in SEO. A marketing site with 5 unique but beautiful (if visibly similar) pages is going to be highly optimized. Blogs aren‚Äôt the only page style (and certainly aren‚Äôt the most efficient) when you‚Äôre trying to build that custom product weight for search placement. Make the job easier: template out your custom page builds!
entry.summary: Cutting-edge web technologies don‚Äôt always document features. Either they lack the ability to convey the full scope of their power from the first release, or they release new features gradually after the MVP. That‚Äôs pretty much the opposite of the old guard of incredible WordPress plugins. A personal favorite static framework of mine is Jekyll, because it‚Äôs simple. But I guess it isn‚Äôt so simple after all.

entry.title: Learn AJAX: Part 2
entry.content:
The universally supported base API for AJAX is called XMLHttpRequest(). We often shorten that to XHR. It is so very much harder for AJAX newcomers to grasp, mostly because the many parts of the HTTP request get separated out into separate pieces of the XHR. If you mess up any of those parts, you won‚Äôt have your data. People want their data. People should read this blog.

This is Part 2 of a tutorial on the basics of AJAX, for beginners. You might want to start at Part 1 if you haven‚Äôt already.

Disclaimer! This article is for beginners, but it does assume a basic knowledge of HTTP‚Äôs structure. If you know the meaning of GET and POST, read on! Otherwise, I highly recommend going straight to the Wikipedia source and boning up.

While I do expect you to know what HTTP requests are, I‚Äôm not expecting you to be familiar with our forefathers and their seminal work on making HTTP requests by hand with web servers. You are not (yet) that server gal üßõ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. You are not (yet) Richmond.

cURL is Really Capitalized Like That

In the beginning, there was a thing called cURL. It underpins a lot of HTTP requests from languages like PHP. It still exists, and it‚Äôs used in many places. Part of it is worth explaining here, but the rest can always be found here.

cURL is cool because it‚Äôs a playground for talking to the internet without a GUI. It can be used as a command line tool, and it lets you build custom HTTP requests from your terminal! cURL is a good place to learn about HTTP, which you already know, right? I hope so.

For each section of an HTTP request, cURL has an option. There are naturally many options. They are grouped by type, like headers, cookies, urls, post-types, and ports. There are many defaults, but it‚Äôs common to need to set more than one of these before executing the actual request. It‚Äôs similar in XHR.

But First, You Must Instantiate!

In my opinion, XHR is the closest thing that old-timey JavaScript can have to a class. It has a lot of sensitive settings, and there can be more than one at a time, so the first thing you‚Äôll do is use the XMLHttpRequest() cookie cutter and stamp out a new Object.

Tell It What You Want

The next part of a POST request will often require specific headers. It‚Äôs possible and common to use these headers to set encoded OAuth keys and values into the request to open up gateways with APIs. It‚Äôs also common to use headers to define your data. You know, normal HTTP header things go here. Naturally, this must always be done after you .open() your request and before you .send() it.

Make It An Event

Your response is now today years old! But what happens when it grows up, travels the world, and returns home? You can set your event handler next, with any callbacks you need.

Wrap Things Up

All that to send some formData. If you recall from Part 1, we were attempting to AJAX this wee little form:

Of course you‚Äôre welcome to send any sort of data string you please via HTTP. With the URLSearchParams() API you can even transform JSON and JS Objects into useful parameters.

Whatever happens, you‚Äôre now ready to send that little form‚Äôs contents out into the big, big world. Give it the boot with .send(). If this were a GET request, .send() would accept the parameters on the url you‚Äôre looking to pull from. It can also accept null.

Examples of XHR with GET and POST

POST

GET

A Short Rant

This was the way I think you should learn about XHR. After jQuery, and before Fetch and Axios.

On the other hand, this is how Mozilla thinks you should learn XHR. There are no base examples, only a long list of properties and methods. Navigating to Using XHR is a real doozy. It contains no single example of a POST request, but instead jumps off on a multi-section tangent about recreating native form submissions. I usually highly recommend the Moz Docs, but in this case you should approach with caution.

Next Time‚Ä¶

We‚Äôve completed the average jQuery AJAX request, and followed through the base XHR request, but two modern AJAX-friendly APIs have been integrated in modern front-end frameworks. The basics of Axios and Fetch will round out our triad of beginner tutorials on asynchronous JavaScript calls.

It is so very much harder for AJAX newcomers to grasp, mostly because the many parts of the HTTP request get separated out into separate pieces of the XHR. If you mess up any of those parts, you won‚Äôt have your data. People want their data. People should read this blog.

entry.title: An Ode to the Object
entry.content:
Let‚Äôs talk about my best friend, JavaScript Object Notation. You probably call that jay-son. If you‚Äôre really particular or feeling a little bit French, maybe you call it jase-on. Whichever way you call it, you‚Äôre almost talking about an associative array.

JSON is cool because it helps me to organize my thoughts and store them. Or maybe somebody else‚Äôs thoughts. Or maybe dynamically generated thoughts. Whatever I want really. If I have a dataset I‚Äôd prefer it to come on over in JSON format, so I can make sense of it right away.

It‚Äôs also cool because it sounds like ‚ÄòJason‚Äô, so people (including me) often intentionally use it when they‚Äôre discussing JavaScript Objects. Talking about Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) quickly turns into a whole thing about how awesome Objects are in many other ways. When I say JSON, you immediately know that I‚Äôm thinking about associative and iterable data and I‚Äôm not going to talk you to sleep about inheritance and scope. Not this time. Hey, wake up.

I‚Äôm going to primarily reference JavaScript here but because an [associative array / map / symbol table / dictionary] is an abstract data type, we could happily discuss this in all of the languages. But not all of the languages are cool enough to tie this to their basic Object structure, nor to have catchy, human-sounding names for things.

Here are some languages.

a Ruby Hash

a Python Dict

a PHP Array

a JavaScript Object

a JSON

Well, that all looks almost the same. I don‚Äôt want to get into why there are different names in each, and I don‚Äôt want to talk about all of the little differences between languages, but it‚Äôs cool to note that your everyday Object in JS is an associative array (and vice versa).

It‚Äôs also really important to carefully observe the difference between a JS Object and JSON. The name shouldn‚Äôt surprise you that JSON is the string notation of your associative array. It‚Äôs a string, and most of its superpowers are not unlocked until you use JSON.parse(yourJSON) to convert that carefully confected data-tree into an Object. And if you want it back to JSON, you can always JSON.stringify(yourObject).

You are likely going to be pushing something toward a JS-based front-end, and you are likely going to be translating whichever associative array you choose into JSON at some point. And don‚Äôt worry about translating it either, because whatever language you‚Äôre using has some function like to_json(), json_encode(), talk_js_to_me() that will make it JSON immediately or slightly sooner than that.

Even stranger, at RANDOM TIMES I REGARD AS MAGIC, sometimes jQuery parses your JSON to a JS Object automatically ‚ú®. The most standard and known time this happens is jQuery AJAX. When the MIME-type data-JSON is in an HTTP header, jQuery will assume you are wanting that data, and help you to get it right now.

JQ also sometimes parses JSON when you‚Äôre dealing with HTML data attributes. And it sometimes does this for no reason at all. I promise. There are tiny gnomes living in your computer that make things happen.

That makes the most famous and important JS debugging tool console.log() important when things go wrong. If your output is showing [object Object] you‚Äôve gone and printed an Object. You need to JSON.stringify() it. If you‚Äôre getting empty brackets {} you might have over-parsed it. Modern browser consoles will happily output things that make this easier on you:

I digress.

But hey, I‚Äôm excited to shout from the rooftops that JSON is my main groovy thing of the moment. JSON does so many of the things I want it to do. It doesn‚Äôt hurt that parsed JSON can become an Object. So I can use it in fancy ways, really any ways, and it reacts like I expect.

That means I can use this to do some weird things. I was making a game somewhat like this:

Woah wait a second‚Ä¶

Yeah that last one took me a little while to figure out. The JQuery object $('#shooter') is just another object inside of the Object. So I could potentially just implement this variable after the document is ready, hope it doesn‚Äôt change, and treat it like the selector itself:

Or maybe I just have a bazillion selectors and I‚Äôm keeping track of them in some new way:

Everything is Objects!

Hurray Objects! Life is fun again, water tastes sweet, the sun is shining, I can choose to ignore OOP principals and data storage methods and just pour all of my data into a stringifyable Object. But that Object is also an associative array. I can do all of the important array things, like iterate ü¶π‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

That‚Äôs pretty much how I made this blog index. I was using Ruby at the time, but it is a very common part of my day-to-day.

Hide JSON Everywhere

Iterating over things is so useful when you‚Äôre storing data in HTML. Using JS data attributes is also a good place to store JSON for later.

You can store it visibly on the HTML as well. But make sure you surround it in single quotes!

So there you have it

JSON is cool. You‚Äôll benefit by using it from time to time. Or all the time. That JSON is a cool guy. And there‚Äôs going to be a separate blog about data attributes. Because it needs to be explained, and I write blogs! That feels like a separate discussion. Check back soon.

entry.title: Pay for Web Development
entry.content:
My first ‚Äòofficial‚Äô web project was for an old friend, a successful musician with a 5-year-old single page with some links. I was so confident in my delivery that I told him I‚Äôd do the project for free! This is bad business, but it wasn‚Äôt the worst part. After hours and hours of collaborative design ideation and development, he went out and bought a subscription to a site generator.

Every developer you know has a similar story. There‚Äôs something ephemeral and subjective about web design and development. It‚Äôs not a physical product that you can be proud to walk home with, and the difference between success and failure feels technical and difficult to quantify.

It probably feels like that because small businesses are long-term investments, and the impacts of marketing don‚Äôt increase revenue immediately. There are actually plenty of ways to show how better development affects your business. I‚Äôll list a few here.

Time

This is the most easily quantifiable value when it comes to your site. A quick search will tell you that 0.9 seconds will slice off a quarter of your user conversion rates. But skimming 0.9 seconds is rarely straightforward. Here‚Äôs a short list of custom troubleshooting thoughts that a web developer naturally has when it comes to speed:

  • Server calls
  • Server allocation
  • Caching: server-side and browser-side
  • Session maintenance
  • Content Delivery Networks
  • Enqueuing and script bloat
  • Browser support
  • Webpacking, autoprefixing, and minification
  • Limited redirection
  • Image Optimization
  • Preloading

Sure, we developers think of all of these things on almost every site, but the true beauty of custom web development is that it‚Äôs straight up impossible to match all of that customization with a website generator. The premise alone means your site will be built on a server, with inevitable work-arounds for pre-compiling the styles you choose to your specifications.

That‚Äôs one of the reasons I say WordPress probably isn‚Äôt for you. A big, multi-tool site is naturally going to be slower and clunkier.

Accessibility

The common consensus is that 20% of people who use the internet have a form of disability. The most common accessibility issues come from mouse use and visibility. Without tools for screen readers and proper mapping and organization, your site will literally stop a fifth of your viewers from accessing the content.

Building a properly accessible site is notoriously difficult. Go to a site like Amazon and try to navigate with only your keyboard. Now go to your favorite blog and try it. This level of accessibility and site architecture requires a tailored approach.

Money

This blog started when that developer‚Äôs friend said ‚Äúbut why does it cost more than [WYSIWYG site generator].‚Äù But your long term costs will actually shrink when you do the job right the first time. Site generating services intentionally charge an extra few dollars more per month. They‚Äôre in it for the long game.

Compound that with licensed code that you may not reuse or download. Proprietary domain names that you can‚Äôt take with you. And generally terrible migrations. Check the fine print before you sign! It‚Äôs like renting an apartment - you‚Äôre not allowed to take it with you when you leave.

There are degrees of separation to be sure. Want a cheap site? Hire a new developer! But be forewarned: make sure that even that budget developer knows what she or he is doing. Development consultants charge incredibly high premiums for ‚Äòcave dives‚Äô into other developers‚Äô code. Cheap code smells like bigger problems.

Your ‚ÄúSeongsu Style‚Äù

When I was doing a very different kind of program development in Seoul, South Korea, I had the opportunity to work directly with a few of the country‚Äôs best interior designers and architects. They walked into hollow shells of construction sites and saw things that noone else could see. They came back with plans that brought out the best parts of a space. Everything they did seemed so ‚Ä¶ apparent! But without them it would have never been done.

You are a unique individual, with a unique business. Highlighting your value and talent is a web developer‚Äôs job. It might make perfect sense after it‚Äôs all done, but it took work and experience. The addage goes something like this: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre only paying me for 5 hours, but you‚Äôre asking me for 5 years‚Äô experience.‚Äù

And there‚Äôs going to be something you want to change, just the eensiest, tiniest bit. If you haven‚Äôt contracted someone who can smooth that out, that little thing is going to bother you every time you visit your own site.

Remember, you will be your site‚Äôs top visitor. It‚Äôs about you after all!

We‚Äôre Not Only Here for the Main Project

Hiring a professional to design and develop will make a huge difference in the lasting success of your site. It‚Äôs faster, more accessible, and often a more accurate representation of your business needs and goals.

Every situation is unique, and the choice is a major one. It‚Äôs a big decision, and one you need to make with all the facts. If you‚Äôre on the fence about it, hire a consult! The fee for a recommendation will be significantly cheaper than the cost of fixing a mistake.

After hours and hours of collaborative design ideation and development, he went out and bought a subscription to a site generator.

entry.title: You Should Probably Jamstack That
entry.content:
I use WordPress all day every day. It‚Äôs extremely customizable and easy for both web administrators and developers. But you don‚Äôt need WordPress. You need Jamstack.

Top Hat makes custom WordPress sites that are both deliciously beautiful and incredibly easy to use. I work with a lot of small- and medium-sized businesses and their marketing sites. I also freelance for up-and-coming businesses and people who consider their budgets a bit lower. I‚Äôm even a participating member of WP Pittsburgh, the group for small business owners and developers who study and practice all things WordPress. But I‚Äôm still here telling you that ‚Ä¶ you probably don‚Äôt need it.

Type your hosting fee here, then click the button.

There‚Äôs got to be a catch, you say. I get what I pay for. I‚Äôm going to drop quality somewhere. Maybe I won‚Äôt get a custom url? Maybe I have to choose from a gaudy design template, or worse, use a clunky website editor like it‚Äôs 2005 and I‚Äôm building a MySpace profile. Is it going to be slow? It‚Äôll probably be really slow.

It‚Äôs true that if you‚Äôre paying for a little server you‚Äôre probably not getting the maximum speed out of your site. And if you‚Äôre hosting tons and tons of data like a forum or a video library you will need a place to store it (and that gets expensive in its own right). But why use a server at all? This is the decade of STATIC SITES.

Static Site
A website that downloads everything to your browser and processes things from there [browser-based]
A website that can connect to everything without querying a hosting server many times [pre-rendered]

You‚Äôve probably heard of this before. These days it‚Äôs called the Jamstack, or JavaScript, APIs and Markup, which is an easier way of thinking about its key components. But we should start from the beginning of JAM. Or is it the end?

M[arkup]

Some History

Actually, static sites have been around since the 1990‚Äôs. Back before every page needed login credentials, when the internet was a small place with anonymous pages, many of those pages were static HTML markup. They were quick, available to everyone, and cheap on server resources. That‚Äôs the definition of a marketing site!

So why isn‚Äôt everything static? Your own technical experience, for starters. Early static sites required experience with HTML at a bare minimum. Adding assets like audio, images, and video dynamically and styling the results was a big ask. A graphical interface for uploading media? Forget it.

That‚Äôs where WordPress came in, and that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs been the king for almost 20 years. It provides a cool(ish) GUI that will help your marketing people get the job done without getting encumbered by strange {curly braces} and $weird_Naming_Conventions.

But today we‚Äôve got Ghost and Forestry bringing the heat without the cost of a fire. These give you the freedom to use good-looking interfaces and a Google Docs-style text editor, and their base plans are free!

A[PIs]

You Probably Don‚Äôt Need to Log In. But If You Do‚Ä¶

You‚Äôre not making Facebook 3.0. You‚Äôre not asking for a number-munching Site as a Service. You‚Äôre just trying to get visibility. Any dynamic experience you need to give your customers could come from a simple cookie.

If that last sentence sounded like gibberish, talk to me later

But even if you are, modern web development uses these cool things called REST APIs for a lot of heavy lifting. These are tiny applications that talk to your site from afar, and deliver content you need on request. The speed improvement compared to building dynamic content on the page is readily apparent. Those large media and file databases we spoke of earlier can still exist independently of your site, and they don‚Äôt need to slow you down.

That includes eCommerce. There is no reason to set up your products on a service like Shopify or WooCommerce, then set them up again inside of your own site. Do it once, and then interface with it. Hence Application Programming Interface. Heck, you can even use SnipCart and it will do most of the integrating for you. ‚úåÔ∏è

J[avaScript]

And then there was JavaScript

Wix costs up to $500 a month for fancy templates. WordPress plugins will quickly rack up site costs for functionality. But a one-size-fits-all solution, built to scale to any size, also adds a lot of dead weight. All the processing work for a page to render on a server quickly becomes more taxing than an API, and rarely is anything new actually getting done.

A savvy developer could template and build a lightweight, fully custom site to your exact specifications. But actually there‚Äôs more than that! What if your site could preload the next page‚Äôs images while you read, or hack the browser to stop it from reloading content it already has? That‚Äôs possible with modern JavaScript frameworks like React, Angular, and Vue.

I strongly encourage you to hit F12 and take a look at all the crazy things a simple blog like this needs to load and give to every browser that visits. Search engine meta, styles, JS libraries to make things scroll smoothly‚Ä¶ on a standard hosted site it will all load again on every click. Storing it properly and only loading new things adds serious speed. I‚Äôm talking blazingly, ludicrously fast.

So that‚Äôs the MAJ‚Äì I mean‚Äì Jamstack, and it‚Äôs going to separate you from your competition. All you need is the right developer. And save all of the hosting costs! That hosting money is much better spent on web consultancy, or invested in the development of the site itself.

After that it‚Äôs 100% yours. You can build out additional pages to your needs, and fill it up with content that will directly attract your clientele. You can even sell products. All without that monthly hosting fee.
entry.summary: I use WordPress all day every day. It‚Äôs extremely customizable and easy for both web administrators and developers. But you don‚Äôt need WordPress. You need Jamstack.
